repo.description: Vim-fork focused on extensibility and usability
repo.name: neovim

body:
docs: adding linux arm64 codeblocks

Problem:
There were no codeblocks to install neovim on linux machines with arm64 architectures

Solution:
Updated the `INSTALL.md` with new codeblocks

comment_data.body:
we really don't need excruciating detail for everything. if arm is more common now, then remove the x86_64 section above, and just mention something like.

people who can't figure out how to apply these instructions to the Release page, should not be using computers.

```suggestion
(For x86_64, replace "arm64" with "x86_64")
```
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -115,26 +119,51 @@ sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
 
 Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
 
-    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```
+
+For arm64:

comment_data.body: no. this doesn't need syntax highlighting.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -115,26 +119,51 @@ sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
 
 Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
 
-    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```
+
+For arm64:
+
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-arm64.tar.gz
+sudo rm -rf /opt/nvim
+sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux-arm64.tar.gz
+```
+
+Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
+
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-arm64/bin"
+```
 
 ### AppImage ("universal" Linux package)
 
-The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old.) The following instructions assume an `x86_64` architecture; on ARM Linux replace with `arm64`.
+The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old).
+
+For x86_64:
 
-    curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    ./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```

@@ -115,26 +119,51 @@ sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux-x86_64.tar.gz
 
 Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
 
-    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-x86_64/bin"
+```
+
+For arm64:
+
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-arm64.tar.gz
+sudo rm -rf /opt/nvim
+sudo tar -C /opt -xzf nvim-linux-arm64.tar.gz
+```
+
+Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
+
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim-linux-arm64/bin"
+```
 
 ### AppImage ("universal" Linux package)
 
-The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old.) The following instructions assume an `x86_64` architecture; on ARM Linux replace with `arm64`.
+The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old).
+
+For x86_64:
 
-    curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    ./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```
 
 To expose nvim globally:
 
-    mkdir -p /opt/nvim
-    mv nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage /opt/nvim/nvim
+```sh
+mkdir -p /opt/nvim

 Then add this to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):

 ### AppImage ("universal" Linux package)
 
-The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old.) The following instructions assume an `x86_64` architecture; on ARM Linux replace with `arm64`.
+The [Releases](https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases) page provides an [AppImage](https://appimage.org) that runs on most Linux systems. No installation is needed, just download `nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage` and run it. (It might not work if your Linux distribution is more than 4 years old).
+
+For x86_64:
 
-    curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
-    ./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```sh
+curl -LO https://github.com/neovim/neovim/releases/latest/download/nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+chmod u+x nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+./nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage
+```
 
 To expose nvim globally:
 
-    mkdir -p /opt/nvim
-    mv nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage /opt/nvim/nvim
+```sh
+mkdir -p /opt/nvim
+mv nvim-linux-x86_64.appimage /opt/nvim/nvim
+```
 
 And the following line to your shell config (`~/.bashrc`, `~/.zshrc`, ...):
 
-    export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim/"
+```sh
+export PATH="$PATH:/opt/nvim/"

comment_data.body: same as above: pick one, either arm or x86. whichever is more common for linux users. we aren't going to repeat every variation of everything in excruciating detail.

Well, it is like this in the MacOS section, I dont understand why should the Linux users have to do it manually instead of just copy the codeblock and paste it on the terminal for the installation.

But ok. If you dont feel this necesary, close the pull request. Ive been waiting for more than a month for a review and I wont be the one that closes it. I will just keep my gist with the installation commands for arm architechture.

Thank you.
